Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that the first Statue of Liberty given to the U.S. by France was a Black woman, which is not supported by historical evidence.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no evidence or historical record to back up the assertion that the U.S. rejected a Black woman Statue of Liberty.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes the problematic assumption that the current Statue of Liberty in New York Harbor is not the original one and that it was replaced by a different version.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the only Statue of Liberty ever given to the U.S. is currently in New York Harbor, as supported by historical evidence.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert provides an alternative explanation that the rumors about a Black Statue of Liberty could have originated from earlier plans made by the designer for a different project, which were never realized.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by presenting a misleading image of the Statue of Liberty on the island of St. Martin as the original Black woman Statue of Liberty, when in fact it is a different statue installed in 2007.
